description: End of class quiz for Session 1: Variables, Storage, and Output

questions.question: If a variable is like a labeled box in a warehouse, what does the label represent?
questions.explanation: The variable name is the label‚Äîit tells you which box (variable) you're referring to, while the contents are the stored value.

questions.question: What happens in memory when you write: score = 100
options: A space called 'score' is created and 100 is placed inside
The computer checks if score equals 100
questions.explanation: The = sign means 'store this value in this named location'. 'score' becomes a container holding 100.

questions.question: What is the main job of print() in a program?
options: To show information to the user
questions.explanation: print() is for output‚Äîit displays messages, numbers, or variable values so the user can see them.

questions.question:
What will appear on screen after this code runs?

player = "Alex"
print(player)
questions.explanation: print(player) shows the value stored in the variable 'player', which is the text Alex (without quotes).

questions.question: Why does Python treat '25' differently from 25?
options: '25' is text you can't do math with, 25 is a number you can calculate
One is bigger than the other
questions.explanation: Quotes mean 'text' (string). No quotes mean 'number' (integer). You can add 25 + 5, but not '25' + 5.

questions.question: Which line stores a piece of text?
questions.explanation: Text must be inside quotes. Words without quotes will cause an error (Python thinks they're variable names).

questions.question: Which line will cause a Python error?
questions.explanation: Variable names cannot contain spaces. Use underscore: player_name = "Sam".

questions.question: You're making a game and need to store the player's high score. Which is correct?
questions.explanation: Variable name with underscores, storing a number (no quotes) so you can update it with math later.

questions.question:
What does this program do?

fruit = "apple"
print(fruit)
fruit = "banana"
print(fruit)
questions.explanation: Variables can change. First print shows 'apple', then fruit gets a new value ('banana'), second print shows 'banana'.

questions.question: Why do programmers use variables instead of typing values directly every time?
options: To reuse and change data easily in one place
Because print() doesn't work without them
Variables make the program run slower
questions.explanation: Variables let you store data once, use it many times, and update it in one place‚Äîmaking programs flexible and easier to maintain.

title: Session 1: Variables & Print - End of Class Quiz
